title: Petechiae: Causes and Treatment
author: Matt McMillen, Stephanie Watson

sections.heading: What Are Petechiae?
content: Petechiae are tiny red, flat spots that appear on your skin. They are a sign of blood leaking from capillaries under your skin. Capillaries are the tiniest blood vessels that connect arteries to veins. They help move oxygen and nutrients from your bloodstream to your organs and tissues. They also carry waste away from your organs and tissues.

Petechiae sometimes appear in clusters and may look like a rash. If you have tiny red, purple, or brown spots on your skin , they could be petechiae. They're not a disease, but a symptom. Several things, from a severe coughing fit to an infection, can cause petechiae.

Often, petechiae are nothing to worry about. Still, it's always a good idea to check with your doctor if you're not sure where these spots came from. Some conditions that cause petechiae are very serious.
Petechiae are more common in kids. If your child has this rash , especially with a fever , take them to a pediatrician right away.

sections.heading: Petechiae leukemia
content: Often referred to as "leukemia spots," these petechiae are a symptom of leukemia. This form of cancer causes your bone marrow to produce large numbers of abnormal white blood cells, which eventually overwhelm your normal blood cells. This makes you more prone to infection. Leukemia also makes your blood less able to clot normally when capillaries burst and bleed beneath your skin. That’s why petechiae form in leukemia.
Petechiae leukemia typically:
Remain the same color if you press on them
bullets: Develop in small clusters on your hands, arms, legs, feet, and, less commonly, in your mouth, on your eyelids, or other parts of your body

sections.heading: What Do Petechiae Look Like?
content: Petechiae are flat and look like pinpoint-sized red, brown, or purple dots. Clumps of petechiae on your skin look like a rash. But unlike many rashes , when you press on the spots they don't turn white. If the spots are larger and red or purple, you may have another type of bleeding problem called purpura.

sections.heading: Petechiae Diagnosis
content: Petechiae with a fever in adults or children can be a sign of a serious, potentially deadly infection such as meningococcal disease . Go to the ER. This disease can progress very rapidly and should be considered a medical emergency.
The doctor will examine you or your child, look at the rash, and ask about symptoms and recent illnesses. Blood and urine tests may help pinpoint the cause of the spots.
Other serious illnesses can also cause petechiae in you or your child. If petechiae spots develop, look out for these other symptoms:

sections.heading: Trouble breathing.
content: Shortness of breath or trouble breathing along with petechiae can be a sign of a serious condition called endocarditis. Endocarditis means there’s an infection in the lining of the inner chambers of the heart and the heart valves.
Confusion. Petechiae -- along with confusion -- could indicate Rocky Mountain spotted fever, an infection caused by the bite of a tick.

Change in consciousness. Some infections caused by viruses, known as viral hemorrhagic fevers, can cause changes in consciousness as well as show signs of petechiae. These diseases include dengue, yellow fever, Lassa, Marburg, and Ebola. They’re found in tropical countries, and cases in the U.S. are usually from people who traveled to these areas.
Petechiae vs. purpura
Petechiae are a type of purpura, spots caused by bleeding beneath the skin. Petechiae measure less than 4 millimeters (mm) in diameter, while purpura are larger, measuring 4-10 mm in diameter.
Petechiae vs. ecchymosis

Ecchymosis is what doctors call a bruise. Like petechiae, they’re caused when blood leaks from damaged blood vessels beneath your skin. However, ecchymoses (the plural of ecchymosis) are much larger. They measure at least 1 centimeter in diameter, or at least 10 times larger than purpura.

sections.heading: Petechiae Treatment and Home Remedies
content: The rash itself doesn't need treatment. If it’s caused by a virus, the spots should clear up as soon as the infection goes away.
If you think your petechiae might have been caused by a minor incident, such as strenuous coughing, vomiting, or weightlifting, you may be able to take care of it at home by doing the following:
However, petechiae may result from a serious underlying condition, so it is best to consult your doctor when these spots appear.
If you have a bacterial infection , you may need to take antibiotics . Make sure you take the full dose of medicine, even if you start to feel better.

More serious diseases such as meningococcal infections, blood disorders, or cancer may need treatment in a hospital. Your doctor may suggest you see a specialist in infections, blood diseases (hematologist), or cancer (oncologist) to oversee your care.
How long do petechiae last?

It depends. Often, petechiae clear up on their own within a few days. However, the timeline depends on the cause. If an illness triggered them, they may stick around or continue to spread until you’ve been treated.

sections.heading: Petechiae: When to Worry
content: Petechiae usually don’t indicate a serious health problem. However, they can be a sign of serious illness, including life-threatening infections. This is particularly true for children. If petechiae develop, call your doctor or go to the emergency room if you notice any of the following symptoms:
You also should see your doctor if you don’t know what has caused the petechiae. Although they’re likely harmless, your doctor can confirm if they indicate an illness that requires treatment.

sections.heading: Petechiae Prevention
content: The only way to avoid getting petechiae is by trying to prevent the various conditions that can cause it. Take good care of yourself by:
bullets: Practicing good hygiene, such as washing your hands, brushing your teeth, and sanitizing your living environment. Don’t share personal items (straws, utensils, toothbrushes, etc).

Avoiding procedures that can lead to skin infections, such as getting tattoos and piercings. Pay close attention to your health and see your doctor about fevers and infections that don’t resolve quickly.
Eating fruits and vegetables or taking supplements to ensure you get enough vitamins in your diet.
Getting vaccinated (immunized) to prevent certain types of bacterial meningitis .
Avoiding mosquitoes and ticks by wearing long pants and long-sleeve shirts if you’re in an affected area. Use insect repellents containing DEET.
